metadata.title: Comprehensive Evidence-Based Research on Bipolar Disorder
metadata.description: Authoritative research compilation from NHS, PubMed, WHO, CDC, NICE, EMA, and APA
primary_sources: CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, US)
NICE (National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, UK)

overview.description: A mental health condition characterized by extreme mood swings, including periods of high mood (mania or hypomania) and low mood (depression), affecting mood, energy, activity levels, and functional ability.

general_principles: Symptoms must not be attributable to substance effects or another medical condition
Episodes not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, or delusional disorder
Emphasis on changes in activity and energy alongside mood disturbances

bipolar_i_disorder.criteria: At least one manic episode (major depressive episode common but not required)

manic_episode_definition.duration: At least 7 consecutive days (or any duration if hospitalization necessary)
manic_episode_definition.core_features: Abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood AND abnormally increased activity or energy
manic_episode_definition.required_symptoms: 3 or more symptoms (4 if mood only irritable)
symptoms: More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking
Flight of ideas or racing thoughts
Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation
Excessive involvement in activities with high potential for painful consequences
manic_episode_definition.severity: Marked impairment in functioning, hospitalization necessary, or psychotic features present

bipolar_ii_disorder.criteria: At least one hypomanic episode AND at least one major depressive episode, with no history of full manic episode

hypomanic_episode_definition.core_features: Persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood AND increased activity or energy
hypomanic_episode_definition.required_symptoms: 3 or more symptoms (4 if mood only irritable)
hypomanic_episode_definition.severity: Unequivocal change in functioning observable by others, NOT severe enough to cause marked impairment or require hospitalization, no psychotic features

cyclothymic_disorder.criteria: Numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms (not meeting full criteria) and depressive symptoms (not meeting full criteria) for at least 2 years (1 year in children/adolescents)
cyclothymic_disorder.exclusions: Criteria for major depressive, manic, or hypomanic episodes never met during this period

major_depressive_episode.required_symptoms: 5 or more symptoms, including depressed mood or loss of interest/pleasure
symptoms: Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day
Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities
Significant weight loss/gain or appetite changes
Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
Decreased ability to think or concentrate
Recurrent thoughts of death or suicidal ideation
major_depressive_episode.impairment: Clinically significant distress or impairment in functioning

specifiers: With rapid cycling (4+ mood episodes in 12 months)

icd11.nomenclature: Bipolar disorders (updated from 'bipolar affective disorders' in ICD-10)
icd11.organizational_structure: Grouped under 'Bipolar or Related Disorders', with 'Mood Disorders' as superordinate grouping
icd11.building_blocks_approach: Mood episodes (depressive, manic, mixed, hypomanic) described first; longitudinal pattern determines diagnosis
icd11.bipolar_i_disorder: At least one past or present manic or mixed episode (depressive episodes may occur but not obligatory)
icd11.bipolar_ii_disorder: At least one hypomanic episode and major depressive episode, no history of manic episodes

manic_episode.core_criteria: Extreme and persistent mood changes (euphoria, irritability, expansiveness, mood lability) AND abnormally increased activity or subjective experience of increased energy
manic_episode.accessory_symptoms: Several of the following: increased talkativeness, flight of ideas, increased self-esteem/grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, distractibility, impulsive/reckless behavior, increased goal-directed activity
manic_episode.duration: Most of the day, nearly every day for minimum 1 week (unless shortened by treatment/hospitalization)
manic_episode.functional_impairment: Significant impairment in all areas of functioning, potentially requiring intensive treatment or hospitalization, may include psychotic symptoms

hypomanic_episode.functional_impairment: Significant change in usual mood and behavior apparent to those who know the individual well, does NOT involve marked impairment or psychosis

icd11.mixed_episodes: Retained in ICD-11 (several prominent manic and depressive symptoms occurring simultaneously or alternating rapidly for at least 2 weeks)
icd11.cyclothymic_disorder: 2-year period with multiple hypomanic and dysthymic symptoms not reaching threshold for mania or formal depressive episode; symptoms can cause significant impairment
key_differences_from_dsm5: ICD-11 retains mixed episodes as separate category
ICD-11 maintains bereavement exclusion for depressive episodes
ICD-11 retains dysthymic disorder as separate entity
Less restrictive criteria for hypomanic functional impairment

bipolar_i.uk_description: Characterised by at least one manic episode, which may be preceded or followed by hypomanic or major depressive episodes
bipolar_i.us_description: Characterized by at least one manic episode, which may be preceded or followed by hypomanic or major depressive episodes
bipolar_i.severity: Most severe form, with full manic episodes

bipolar_ii.description: At least one hypomanic episode and one major depressive episode, without full manic episodes
bipolar_ii.characteristics: Hypomania less severe than mania, but depressive episodes can be equally severe

cyclothymic_disorder.uk_description: Chronic fluctuating mood disturbance with numerous hypomanic and depressive symptoms that do not meet full criteria for episodes
cyclothymic_disorder.us_description: Chronic fluctuating mood disturbance with numerous hypomanic and depressive symptoms that do not meet full criteria for episodes
cyclothymic_disorder.duration: At least 2 years (1 year in children/adolescents)

rapid_cycling.definition: Four or more distinct mood episodes within 12 months
rapid_cycling.prevalence: Occurs in 10-20% of bipolar disorder cases
rapid_cycling.characteristics: More common in women, associated with worse prognosis

mixed_episodes.uk_description: Simultaneous or rapidly alternating manic and depressive symptoms
mixed_episodes.us_description: Simultaneous or rapidly alternating manic and depressive symptoms

clinical_assessment_components: Detailed psychiatric history including mood episodes
Risk assessment (self-harm, suicide, harm to others)

nice_recommendations.primary_care: Inquire about previous periods of overactivity or disinhibited behaviour lasting 4+ days when adults present with depression
nice_recommendations.specialist_assessment: Full psychiatric assessment in service capable of offering comprehensive interventions
nice_recommendations.questionnaire_use: Should NOT be used in primary care to identify bipolar disorder

conditions_to_consider.key_differences: No history of manic or hypomanic episodes; bipolar disorder often misdiagnosed as MDD initially
Psychotic symptoms persist beyond mood episodes in schizophrenia; negative symptoms more prominent
Psychotic symptoms occur in absence of mood episodes
Mood instability more reactive to interpersonal events; identity disturbance; chronic pattern
Symptoms present since childhood; no distinct mood episodes; different quality of symptoms
Mood symptoms directly related to substance use/withdrawal; temporal relationship crucial

conditions_to_consider.examples: Hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism, Cushing's syndrome, multiple sclerosis, brain tumours
conditions_to_consider.key_differences: Physical examination and laboratory tests reveal underlying medical cause

misdiagnosis_statistics.prevalence: Up to 76.8% of individuals with bipolar disorder experience misdiagnosis
misdiagnosis_statistics.diagnostic_delay: Average 5-10 years from symptom onset to correct diagnosis
misdiagnosis_statistics.racial_disparities: African-American men 25% more likely to be misdiagnosed with schizophrenia vs 7% for Caucasian men

general_principles: Bipolar disorder cannot be cured but can be effectively managed
Treatment combines pharmacological and psychosocial interventions
Shared decision-making with patients and carers
treatment_goals: Reduce severity and frequency of episodes
Improve functioning and quality of life

mood_stabilisers.overview: Cornerstone of bipolar disorder treatment for acute episodes and long-term maintenance

medications.name: Lithium
medications.efficacy: Gold standard with strongest evidence for long-term relapse prevention
monitoring_requirements: ECG in patients with cardiac risk factors
medications.pregnancy_considerations: Avoid if possible, especially first trimester (risk of Ebstein's anomaly); if essential, use lowest effective dose with careful monitoring
medications.nice_guidance: Should not be initiated in primary care except under shared-care arrangements
predictors_of_response: Family history of bipolar disorder and lithium response

medications.name: Valproate (Valproic acid, Divalproex sodium)
indications: Maintenance treatment (especially for atypical forms, rapid cycling, dysphoric mania)
medications.efficacy: Effective for acute mania and maintenance; particularly useful for rapid cycling and mixed states

mhra_ema_restrictions: Must NOT be initiated in individuals under 55 years unless two specialists independently agree no other effective/tolerated treatment exists
Must NOT be used in women and girls of childbearing potential unless other options unsuitable AND Pregnancy Prevention Programme in place
Boys and men must use effective contraception during treatment and for 3 months after stopping
Men planning family within next year should discuss fertility risks with healthcare professional
teratogenic_risks: 11% risk of malformations in babies if taken during pregnancy
30-40% risk of developmental disorders in children exposed in utero
Includes neural tube defects, facial abnormalities, limb defects, cardiac malformations
pregnancy_prevention_programme_requireme: Pregnancy tests before starting and regularly during treatment

medications.nice_guidance: Should not be initiated in primary care
medications.ema_authorisation: Treatment of manic episode in bipolar disorder when lithium is contraindicated or not tolerated; continuation after manic episode may be considered in responders
medications.fda_approval: Acute mania (divalproex); acute mania and mixed episodes (divalproex extended release)

medications.name: Lamotrigine
indications: Long-term maintenance (especially for preventing depressive episodes)
medications.efficacy: Strong evidence for preventing depressive relapses; modest effect in acute bipolar depression
medications.titration: Requires slow dose escalation over several weeks to reduce risk of serious rash
side_effects: Rash (including Stevens-Johnson syndrome - rare but serious)
medications.monitoring: Clinical monitoring for rash, especially during titration
medications.pregnancy_considerations: Relatively safer than valproate; folic acid supplementation recommended

medications.name: Carbamazepine
medications.efficacy: Effective for acute mania; may be better than lithium for rapid cycling
medications.drug_interactions: Significant enzyme inducer - multiple drug interactions
medications.pregnancy_considerations: Avoid if possible; risk of neural tube defects

antipsychotics.overview: Used for acute episodes and maintenance treatment; many have mood-stabilising properties

first_generation_antipsychotics.use: Primarily for acute mania; less commonly used long-term due to side effect profile

second_generation_atypical_antipsychotic.overview: Broader therapeutic spectrum; fewer motor side effects than FGAs

medications.name: Olanzapine
medications.efficacy: Highly effective for acute mania; FDA-approved for bipolar depression (with fluoxetine)
medications.monitoring: Weight, BMI, glucose, lipids, blood pressure

medications.name: Quetiapine
medications.efficacy: Only medication specifically approved by EMA for bipolar depression in adults; effective across all phases
medications.benefits: Can improve sleep quality and comorbid anxiety
medications.nice_recommendations: First-line option for acute mania/hypomania and bipolar depression

medications.name: Risperidone
side_effects: Extrapyramidal symptoms (higher risk than other SGAs)

medications.name: Aripiprazole
medications.mechanism: Partial dopamine D2 receptor agonist (third-generation antipsychotic)
medications.efficacy: Effective for acute mania and maintenance; inconsistent results for bipolar depression
side_effects: Lower risk of weight gain and metabolic effects
medications.ema_approval: Approved for moderate to severe manic episodes in Bipolar I Disorder in adolescents aged 13+

medications.name: Lurasidone
medications.efficacy: Effective for bipolar depression; may improve cognition

medications.name: Cariprazine
medications.mechanism: Partial dopamine D2/D3 receptor agonist (third-generation antipsychotic)
medications.efficacy: Significant antidepressant effect on bipolar depression; effective for mania
medications.fda_approval: Approved for manic and depressive episodes in bipolar disorder

medications.name: Asenapine
medications.efficacy: Effective for acute mania and preventing recurrence

medications.name: Ziprasidone
medications.efficacy: Effective for acute mania; inconsistent results for bipolar depression

medications.name: Lumateperone
medications.mechanism: Partial D3 and 5-HT1A agonist; serotonin transporter inhibitor
medications.fda_approval: Approved for depressive episodes in bipolar I or II disorder

general_considerations: Choice depends on episode type, previous response, side effect profile, patient preference
Combination with mood stabilisers often used
Regular monitoring for metabolic side effects essential
Long-acting injectables available for some agents (improve adherence)

antidepressants.overview: Controversial use in bipolar disorder due to risk of inducing mania
antidepressants.indications: Bipolar depression (only with mood stabiliser or antipsychotic)
recommendations: Should NOT be used as monotherapy
Should NOT be used during manic/hypomanic episodes
SSRIs preferred over tricyclics (lower switch risk)
Combine with mood stabiliser or antipsychotic
antidepressants.evidence: Meta-analyses show limited efficacy in bipolar depression; some studies show no difference from placebo
antidepressants.nice_guidance: Consider stopping antidepressant if person develops mania/hypomania while on antidepressant monotherapy

benzodiazepines.nice_guidance: Can be considered for initial management of acute behavioural disturbance in addition to antimanic agent

general_guidelines: Provide age-appropriate information on medication purpose, side effects, monitoring
Collaborate with individual in medication choice
Discuss impact of alcohol, tobacco, prescription/non-prescription, and illicit drugs
Do not stop medication suddenly without medical guidance
older_people: Consider increased risk of drug interactions
Be aware of anticholinergic effects on cognitive function and mobility

psychotherapy_approaches.overview: Essential adjunct to pharmacotherapy; improves outcomes, adherence, and relapse prevention
general_principles: Should be specifically developed for bipolar disorder or adapted appropriately
Delivered by trained and experienced therapists
Can be individual, group, or family-based

cognitive_behavioural_therapy.description: Structured psychological intervention helping individuals identify and change negative thought patterns and behaviours
cognitive_behavioural_therapy.typical_duration: Average 20 sessions, followed by enhancement sessions

components: Clarify diagnosis using SCID or MINI
Create life chart to identify triggers and early signs
Information about bipolar disorder nature, symptoms, etiology
Explain interaction between environment, thoughts, emotions, physiology, behaviours
Emphasise biological factors and medication importance
Skill development (decision-making, assertiveness, problem-solving, social skills)

efficacy.relapse_reduction: Pooled odds ratio 0.506 for reduced relapse rates
efficacy.depression_improvement: Hedges's g of -0.494 for decreased depression
efficacy.mania_reduction: Hedges's g of -0.581 for reduced mania severity
efficacy.functioning_improvement: Hedges's g of 0.457 for increased psychosocial functioning
efficacy.time_considerations: Most effective in first year; benefits may diminish beyond 18 months without booster sessions

cognitive_behavioural_therapy.nice_recommendations: Second-line adjunctive treatment for acute depression and maintenance phase

family_focused_therapy.description: Involves family members in psychoeducation, communication improvement, and problem-solving
family_focused_therapy.typical_duration: At least 10 planned sessions over 3 months to 1 year
efficacy: Reduces relapse rates compared to individual psychoeducation
family_focused_therapy.nice_recommendations: Should be offered to individuals living with or in close contact with family; second-line adjunctive treatment for acute depression and maintenance

interpersonal_and_social_rhythm_therapy.description: Focuses on stabilising daily routines and interpersonal relationships to regulate mood
key_components: Maintaining consistent daily routines (meals, work, exercise)
efficacy: Associated with delayed recurrences when social and circadian rhythms regulated
interpersonal_and_social_rhythm_therapy.nice_recommendations: Can be offered as psychological intervention for bipolar disorder

psychoeducation.description: Educates individuals and families about bipolar disorder, symptoms, triggers, and management strategies
components: Information about bipolar disorder nature and course

group_psychoeducation: Not effective for preventing depressive relapses
efficacy.individual_psychoeducation: May be less effective than group interventions

psychoeducation.nice_recommendations: Carer-focused education and support program should be offered early
psychoeducation.canmat_isbd_recommendations: First-line adjunctive intervention for all patients

other_psychological_interventions.name: Interpersonal Therapy (IPT)
other_psychological_interventions.description: Focuses on relationships and their impact on mood
other_psychological_interventions.nice_recommendations: Can be offered as choice for bipolar depression

other_psychological_interventions.name: Behavioural Couples Therapy
other_psychological_interventions.description: Involves partner in treatment to improve relationship functioning and mood management
other_psychological_interventions.nice_recommendations: Can be offered as choice for bipolar depression

other_psychological_interventions.name: Peer Interventions
other_psychological_interventions.description: Support from individuals with lived experience of bipolar disorder

other_psychological_interventions.name: Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy
other_psychological_interventions.description: Combines mindfulness practices with cognitive therapy
other_psychological_interventions.status: Promising modality; conflicting results as first-line treatment

other_psychological_interventions.name: Illness Management and Recovery
other_psychological_interventions.description: Structured program for self-management and recovery

lifestyle_interventions.overview: Modifiable lifestyle factors significantly impact bipolar disorder onset, trajectory, and outcomes

sleep_and_circadian_rhythm.importance: Sleep disturbances prominent in bipolar disorder; can trigger mood episodes
recommendations: Aim for 7-9 hours sleep per night
Create conducive sleep environment (dark, quiet, cool)
Regular aerobic exercise (150 minutes moderate intensity per week)
Avoid excessive exercise during manic episodes
Omega-3 fatty acids (may have mood-stabilising properties)
diet_and_nutrition.considerations: Dietary interventions important for improving depressive symptoms and functioning

stress_management.importance: Chronic stress can trigger manic or depressive episodes
techniques: Relaxation techniques (progressive muscle relaxation, deep breathing)

substance_use_avoidance.recommendations: Aggressive screening and management of substance use disorders essential

social_relationships.importance: Healthy social support crucial for mood stability
recommendations: Communicate openly with family and friends

lifestyle_interventions.multidimensional_approach: Research suggests multidimensional lifestyle interventions (addressing multiple domains) may have greater impact than single-domain interventions

emergency_crisis_treatment.overview: Urgent intervention required for severe episodes or risk situations
crisis_situations: Acute risk of self-harm or suicide

assessment: Risk assessment (suicide, self-harm, harm to others)

options: Haloperidol (with caution due to EPS risk)
Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) if medication ineffective or rapid response needed

indications: Severe risk of self-harm or suicide
Lack of adequate support at home
types: Involuntary admission (under Mental Health Act in UK; varies by jurisdiction)

crisis_team_support.description: Community-based intensive support as alternative to hospitalisation when appropriate

indications: Severe depression not responding to medication
Severe mania not responding to medication
Rapid symptom control needed to prevent harm
electroconvulsive_therapy.efficacy: Highly effective for severe episodes; rapid onset of action
electroconvulsive_therapy.procedure: Brief electrical stimulation of brain under general anaesthesia
electroconvulsive_therapy.nice_recommendations: Second-line treatment for acute mania; consider for severe depression
electroconvulsive_therapy.considerations: Better tolerated in elderly; may be considered earlier in this population

other_brain_stimulation_therapies.name: Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS)
other_brain_stimulation_therapies.indications: Bipolar depression not responding to antidepressants
other_brain_stimulation_therapies.status: Being studied; low risk of memory/thinking effects

other_brain_stimulation_therapies.name: Light Therapy
other_brain_stimulation_therapies.efficacy: Effective for seasonal affective disorder; may help bipolar depression with seasonal worsening

other_brain_stimulation_therapies.name: Ketamine
other_brain_stimulation_therapies.status: Under investigation; shows potential for short-term relief of depressive and suicidal symptoms
other_brain_stimulation_therapies.considerations: More research needed for long-term use and guidelines

components: Information on other health problems, medications, allergies
Insurance details and preferred treatment facilities
Actions others should take during crisis
Reasons for living and importance of recovery
crisis_planning.nice_recommendations: Joint risk management plan should be developed with patient and carer, including triggers, early warning signs, coping strategies, medication adjustment protocols, and crisis contact information

us_crisis_contacts: Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741

self_monitoring.importance: Essential for recognising patterns, triggers, and early warning signs

medication_adherence.importance: Critical for preventing relapse and maintaining stability
strategies_to_improve_adherence: Use pill organisers or reminder apps

routine_and_structure.importance: Helps stabilise circadian rhythms and mood

social_support.importance: Strong social support associated with better outcomes
strategies: Maintain connections with supportive family and friends
Educate loved ones about bipolar disorder
Seek peer support from others with lived experience

wellness_recovery_action_plan.description: Structured self-management tool for recognising triggers and relapse signs
components: Early warning signs and action plans
wellness_recovery_action_plan.nice_recommendations: Excellent tool for engaging individuals in self-management

mood_tracking_and_monitoring.importance: Enables early detection of mood changes and informed treatment decisions

digital_tools.overview: Smartphone apps and wearable devices offer convenient, real-time mood monitoring
challenges: Not all apps specifically designed for bipolar disorder

examples.name: eMoods Bipolar Mood Tracker
features: Data stored locally on device (privacy feature)
examples.target_audience: Individuals with bipolar disorder, depression, PTSD, anxiety

examples.name: Bipolar UK Mood Tracker
features: Record daily mood, medications, emotions, sleep

examples.name: PolarUs
features: Measure and monitor quality of life using evidence-backed scale

considerations: Clinicians should inquire about patients' app use
Ensure apps have clear privacy policies
Prefer apps with evidence base and clinical input
Regular review of consumer-facing apps needed

passive_sensing_and_digital_phenotyping.description: Collecting data from smartphone sensors and wearables to infer mental states
challenges: Need for external validation of predictive models
examples: Apps using GPS for activity monitoring

common_triggers.management: Maintain regular sleep-wake schedule; prioritise sleep hygiene; avoid shift work if possible
Stress management techniques; problem-solving; seek support; avoid overcommitment
Avoid alcohol and recreational drugs; limit caffeine; seek treatment for substance use disorders
Maintain medication adherence; discuss concerns with healthcare provider before making changes
Light therapy; maintain routine; monitor mood closely during seasonal transitions
Pace activities; schedule rest periods; set realistic goals; learn to say no
Communication skills; conflict resolution; family therapy; set boundaries
Monitor mood in relation to hormonal changes; discuss with healthcare provider; consider hormonal treatments if appropriate

strategies_for_trigger_management: Keep detailed mood diary to identify personal triggers
Develop action plans for each identified trigger
Modify environment to reduce exposure to triggers when possible
Build coping skills for unavoidable triggers
Regular review of triggers with healthcare provider

sleep_hygiene_and_routine_management.importance: Sleep disturbances both symptom and trigger of mood episodes
sleep_hygiene_recommendations: Maintain consistent sleep-wake schedule (even on weekends)
Create conducive sleep environment (dark, quiet, cool, comfortable)
Limit screen time 1-2 hours before bed
Avoid large meals close to bedtime
Regular physical activity (but not close to bedtime)
Relaxation routine before bed (reading, warm bath, meditation)
Use bed only for sleep and intimacy (not work or TV)
If unable to sleep after 20 minutes, get up and do relaxing activity
monitoring_sleep: Recognise changes in sleep as early warning sign
Use sleep tracking apps or wearables if helpful
when_to_seek_help: Persistent insomnia (difficulty falling or staying asleep)

relapse_prevention.importance: Preventing relapse crucial for long-term stability and quality of life

pharmacological: Maintain mood stabiliser or antipsychotic medication
Prompt adjustment of medication if early warning signs
Long-term maintenance treatment (lithium, valproate, lamotrigine, antipsychotics)
psychological: Regular therapy sessions or booster sessions

pharmacological: Lithium: Strong evidence for preventing all relapses, especially manic
Valproate: Effective for preventing all relapses and depressive relapses
Lamotrigine: Strong evidence for preventing all relapses and depressive relapses
Olanzapine: Effective for preventing all relapses and manic relapses
Quetiapine: Effective for preventing all relapses
Aripiprazole: Effective for preventing manic relapses
psychological: CBT: Effective in first year; may need booster sessions for sustained effect
Group psychoeducation: Effective for preventing overall and manic/hypomanic relapses (NNT 5-8)
Enhanced relapse prevention training for CMHT workers: Increases median time to next episode by ~8.5 weeks

nice_recommendations: Develop joint risk management plan with patient and carer
Include identifiable triggers, early warning signs, coping strategies
Agreements between primary and secondary care for responding to increased risk

specific_considerations: Peer support groups for young people
resources: CAMHS (Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services) - UK

financial_support: Lasting power of attorney (for financial management during episodes)

supporting_loved_ones: Involve other family and friends with consent
communication_strategies: Choose appropriate times for discussions (not during acute episodes)
crisis_planning: Develop crisis plan together when person is well
Understand when to seek urgent help
Know person's preferences for crisis management
Agree on code words for distress
Plan for practical matters (childcare, work, finances)

family_interventions.family_focused_therapy: Evidence-based intervention involving family in treatment
family_interventions.family_psychoeducation: Education about bipolar disorder for family members
family_interventions.nice_recommendations: Family intervention should be offered, ideally involving person with bipolar disorder, for 3 months to 1 year, with at least 10 planned sessions

nice_recommendations: Carers should receive written and verbal information on diagnosis, management, recovery, support available, roles of care teams, and crisis help
Carer-focused education and support program should be offered early
Information sharing between person and carers should be negotiated early
Carers may be entitled to carer's assessment from social care services

resources.services: Resources specifically for family, friends, and carers

self_care_for_carers: Prioritise own physical and mental health

classroom_accommodations: Quiet space for breaks if needed
Extra time for assignments or exams
supporting_students: Be aware of triggers (stress, sleep deprivation)
Communicate regularly with parents/carers and mental health professionals
Ensure student has access to school counsellor or mental health support
Educate other staff about student's needs (with consent)
Have plan for managing crises at school
resources_for_educators: School mental health policies and procedures
Liaison with CAMHS (UK) or school mental health services

best_practices: Collaborative care planning with patient and family
care_coordination: Clear communication between primary and secondary care
Care coordinator or key worker assigned
Shared care protocols for medication management
Crisis plans in place and accessible
Smooth transitions between services (e.g., CAMHS to adult services)

guidelines.name: NICE Guideline CG185
guidelines.title: Bipolar disorder: assessment and management
guidelines.organisation: National Institute for Health and Care Excellence

guidelines.name: CANMAT/ISBD Guidelines
guidelines.title: Guidelines for the management of patients with bipolar disorder
guidelines.organisation: Canadian Network for Mood and Anxiety Treatments / International Society for Bipolar Disorders

guidelines.name: APA Practice Guideline
guidelines.title: Practice Guideline for the Treatment of Patients With Bipolar Disorder

guidelines.name: BAP Guidelines
guidelines.title: Evidence-based guidelines for treating bipolar disorder

guidelines.name: WHO mhGAP Intervention Guide
guidelines.title: Mental Health Gap Action Programme Intervention Guide

training: Family interventions for psychosis and bipolar disorder training (HEE - UK)
Psychological therapy training specific to bipolar disorder
professional_organisations: Canadian Network for Mood and Anxiety Treatments

primary_care: Annual review minimum (more frequent if concerns)
Physical health monitoring (weight, BMI, cardiovascular, metabolic, liver, renal, thyroid function)
Support adherence to care plans and crisis plans
Referral to secondary care if needed
secondary_care: Regular appointments with psychiatrist and/or care coordinator
Medication monitoring (including blood levels for lithium, valproate)
Transition planning (e.g., back to primary care when stable)

addressing_comorbidities: Physical health conditions (diabetes, cardiovascular disease, obesity, thyroid disorders)
Screening and management as per relevant guidelines

early_warning_signs_recognition.importance: Early recognition enables prompt intervention and may prevent full episode
manic_hypomanic_warning_signs: Decreased need for sleep (feeling rested after few hours)
Racing thoughts or mind feeling 'sped up'
Increased goal-directed activity or starting multiple projects
Difficulty concentrating or being easily distracted
depressive_warning_signs: Loss of interest in usual activities
Sleep changes (difficulty sleeping or sleeping too much)
Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
early_warning_signs_recognition.individual_variation: Warning signs can vary between individuals; important to identify personal patterns
monitoring_strategies: Use of mood tracking apps or wearables

immediate_priorities: Ensure safety of individual and others
Assess level of risk (suicide, self-harm, harm to others)
information_gathering: Collateral information from family/carers if possible

for_mania_hypomania: Offer medication if prescribed for acute use
Remove access to credit cards, car keys if impulsive behaviour risk
Contact mental health team or crisis services
Consider hospitalisation if severe or high risk
for_depression: Avoid leaving person alone if suicidal
Contact mental health team or crisis services
Consider hospitalisation if high suicide risk
for_mixed_episodes: Combine strategies for both mania and depression

us: Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741

verbal_techniques: Validate concerns without agreeing with delusional content
non_verbal_techniques: Position yourself at angle rather than directly facing
Remove potential weapons or dangerous objects from environment
environmental_modifications: Provide water or refreshments if appropriate
when_de_escalation_not_working: Consider medication if prescribed and appropriate
May need to involve emergency services

components: Internal coping strategies (things person can do alone)
People and social settings that provide distraction
Professionals or agencies to contact during crisis
Making environment safe (removing means of self-harm)
development_process: Develop collaboratively with person when they are well
Write it down and keep copies accessible
safety_planning.nice_recommendations: Joint risk management plan should be developed with patient and carer, including triggers, early warning signs, coping strategies, medication adjustment protocols, and crisis contact information

during_depression: Be patient and allow time for responses
during_stable_periods: Address concerns about medication or treatment
Review what helps and what doesn't

with_family_and_carers: Respect confidentiality while sharing necessary information
Involve in treatment planning when appropriate
cultural_considerations: Be aware of cultural beliefs about mental illness
Adapt communication style to cultural norms
Involve family in culturally appropriate ways

overview.importance: Digital tools and gamification can enhance engagement, self-management, and treatment outcomes
challenges: Variable quality and evidence base of available apps
Need for apps specifically designed for bipolar disorder
Translational lag from research to publicly available tools

gamification_approaches.definition: Application of game design elements to non-game contexts to boost engagement and motivate behaviour change

general_mental_health: Effectiveness depends on quality and integration of elements
bipolar_disorder_specific: Bipolar disorder among least commonly targeted domains for gamified interventions
Potential for enhancing engagement in mood tracking and self-management
Need for further research on effectiveness and safety

examples.name: eQuoo
examples.description: Gamified mental health app with levels, progress feedback, points, narratives, personalization, mini-games, and badges
examples.evidence: Demonstrated increases in resilience and decreases in anxiety and depression in student population; higher retention than control groups

considerations_for_bipolar_disorder: Ensure game elements don't overstimulate during manic phases
Balance challenge with achievability to avoid frustration during depressive phases
Personalise to individual's current mood state
Involve individuals with lived experience in design

features: Daily mood ratings (visual scales, numerical scales)

quality_of_life_tracking.description: Monitoring broader aspects of wellbeing beyond mood
quality_of_life_tracking.example: PolarUs app uses evidence-backed quality of life scale specific to bipolar disorder

goal_tracking.example: Life Goals app helps align coping strategies with personal goals

reward_and_streak_systems.purpose: Motivate consistent engagement and positive behaviours

types.description: Track consecutive days of app use or healthy behaviours
types.benefits: Encourages consistency; provides sense of achievement
types.considerations: Avoid excessive pressure; allow for 'grace days' during difficult periods

types.examples: 7-day streak, 30-day streak, completing educational modules, consistent mood tracking

types.uses: Can be purely motivational or unlock content/features
types.considerations: Ensure points don't create unhealthy competition or pressure

types.examples: New mood tracking options, relaxation exercises, educational articles
types.benefits: Provides tangible reward; encourages exploration of app features

reward_and_streak_systems.evidence: Suggested by users as potential motivators for app engagement; limited research on effectiveness specifically for bipolar disorder
cautions: Avoid creating pressure that could worsen symptoms
Ensure rewards are meaningful and not trivialising
Focus on intrinsic motivation alongside extrinsic rewards

interactive_management_games.concept: Games designed to teach skills or provide therapeutic benefit
potential_applications: Cognitive training games (attention, memory, executive function)
examples_from_general_mental_health: SPARX (for depression in adolescents) - fantasy game teaching CBT skills
MindLight (for anxiety in children) - neurofeedback game
Personal Investigator (for depression) - detective game with CBT elements
interactive_management_games.bipolar_disorder_specific: Limited examples; area requiring development and research

recommendations_for_users: Look for apps with evidence base or clinical input
Check privacy policy and data security measures
Prefer apps specifically designed for bipolar disorder when available
Discuss app use with healthcare provider
Be aware that apps are adjuncts, not replacements for professional treatment
Monitor own response to app use (helpful vs stressful)
recommendations_for_clinicians: Review data from apps if patient wishes to share
Stay informed about available digital tools
Provide guidance on evaluating app quality

considerations: Diagnosis rare in this age group
digital_tools: Simple mood tracking with visual aids (emoji scales, colour coding)

medications: Aripiprazole approved by EMA for moderate to severe manic episodes in Bipolar I (age 13+)
FDA-approved medications include olanzapine (13+), lithium (12+), quetiapine, risperidone, aripiprazole (10+)

digital_tools: Full range of mood tracking and self-management apps
Focus on medication management and physical health monitoring
elderly.medications: Lower doses recommended; ECT may be considered earlier due to better tolerability

service_terminology.uk: CAMHS (Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services)

us_english_terminology.spelling_differences: See UK English section for comparison

regional_medical_terminology_differences.status: Outdated term for bipolar disorder; still recognised but not preferred
ICD-10 term; updated to 'bipolar disorder' in ICD-11

regional_medical_terminology_differences.uk_usage: Informal term for involuntary admission under Mental Health Act

cultural_considerations: Mental health stigma varies across cultures
Some cultures may have different conceptualisations of mental illness
Family involvement in treatment may be more or less expected depending on culture
Use of interpreters important for non-English speakers
Culturally adapted interventions may be more effective

global_burden.prevalence: Approximately 0.5% of global population (37 million people in 2021)
global_burden.breakdown: 34 million adults and 3.8 million adolescents aged 10-19
global_burden.trends: Global incidence and prevalence showed consistent upward trend from 1990 to 2021
global_burden.regional_variations: Americas had highest YLD number and rate; Southern Latin America saw largest increase in incidence
global_burden.gender: Females and adolescents bear greater burden; higher incidence and prevalence rates
global_burden.who_ranking: Fifth leading cause of disease burden among mental disorders

prevalence.comparison: US has highest lifetime rate (4.4%) among 11 nations studied

age_of_onset.early_onset: Up to one-third of children/adolescents with depression may have early-onset bipolar disorder

gender_distribution.characteristics: Women more likely to experience rapid cycling and depressive episodes; men slightly more prone to manic episodes and younger age at first episode

racial_ethnic_differences.treatment_disparities: Native Hawaiian/Other Pacific Islanders 49% less likely to receive medication; non-Hispanic Blacks 46% less likely compared to non-Hispanic Whites
racial_ethnic_differences.misdiagnosis: African-American men 25% more likely to be misdiagnosed with schizophrenia vs 7% for Caucasian men

treatment_gaps.diagnostic_delay: Average 10 years from symptom onset to correct diagnosis
treatment_gaps.accurate_diagnosis_timeline: Only 1 in 4 get accurate diagnosis in less than 3 years
treatment_gaps.treatment_resistance: 20-30% of Bipolar I patients continue experiencing symptoms despite treatment

united_states.regional_variations: Inpatient stays range from 33.2 per 100,000 (Washington) to 150.6 per 100,000 (Illinois)

united_kingdom.service_provision: NHS provides comprehensive mental health services including specialist bipolar disorder teams
united_kingdom.challenges: Concerns about under-diagnosis, under-treatment, and high threshold for specialist referral

comorbidity.impact: Comorbidities lead to lower use of medical care, reduced treatment adherence, higher risk of adverse outcomes, and reduced life expectancy (13 years shorter than general population)

misdiagnosis.diagnostic_delay: Average 5-10 years from symptom onset to correct diagnosis
misdiagnosis.consequences: Delayed appropriate treatment, inappropriate treatments (e.g., antidepressants alone), worse outcomes
